feature_title: Plural of objects coming in pairs
feature_description: Ibragimov (2004: 52, 126, 149, 152, 172) suggests that some dialects use special pluralization strategies for words denoting objects usually coming in pairs (eyes, legs, etc.). Such plurals are formed from singular absolutive (*ul* ‘eye’, *ʁil* ‘leg’) with formant *-ab*, e.g. *ulab* ‘eyes’, *ʁilab* ‘legs’. Other dialects have regular plurals, e.g. *ulabɨr* ‘eyes’, *ʁilabɨr* ‘legs’. We collected forms of these two nouns using three stimuli: ‘eyes’ (citation context), ‘She has beautiful eyes’ and ‘My legs hurt’. In the case of ‘eyes’, the first reaction always was the form *ulabɨr*. We asked whether the form *ulab* is possible. The map shows the results: **OK ulab** — the form *ulab* is possible, **NO ulab** — it is impossible. As for ‘leg’, we almost always got the form *ʁilabɨr* as the first reaction, except for Myukhrek, where the first reaction was *ʁilab* (but *ʁilabɨr* was also deemed possible). The map shows the results: **OK ʁilab** — the form *ʁilab* is possible, **NO ʁilab** — it is impossible, **ʁilab as first reaction** — a label for Myukhrek only, where, unlike other dialects, this form was the first reaction.
name: Сара

Such plurals are formed from singular absolutive (*ul* ‘eye’, *ʁil* ‘leg’) with formant *-ab*, e.g. *ulab* ‘eyes’, *ʁilab* ‘legs’. Other dialects have regular plurals, e.g. *ulabɨr* ‘eyes’, *ʁilabɨr* ‘legs’. We collected forms of these two nouns using three stimuli: ‘eyes’ (citation context), ‘She has beautiful eyes’ and ‘My legs hurt’. In the case of ‘eyes’, the first reaction always was the form *ulabɨr*. We asked whether the form *ulab* is possible. The map shows the results: **OK ulab** — the form *ulab* is possible, **NO ulab** — it is impossible. As for ‘leg’, we almost always got the form *ʁilabɨr* as the first reaction, except for Myukhrek, where the first reaction was *ʁilab* (but *ʁilabɨr* was also deemed possible). The map shows the results: **OK ʁilab** — the form *ʁilab* is possible, **NO ʁilab** — it is impossible, **ʁilab as first reaction** — a label for Myukhrek only, where, unlike other dialects, this form was the first reaction.
name: тажир
long_periods_outside: учился в дербенте, работал в бабаюртовском районе. но с 86 года тут

feature_title: Plural marker of the noun ‘brother’
feature_description: The singular absolutive of the noun ‘brother’ is either *šuˤ* (attested only in Khnov), *šugu* (attested only in Ikhrek) or *šu* (elsewhere). The attested variants of the plural marker include *-be* (and its phonetic variants) and *-jmar*. The latter forms either a simple — *šugu-jmar* (in Ikhrek), or a double marked plural — *šu-be-jmar* (and its phonetic variants). The map shows the distribution of the variants.
name: Сара
comment: фарингализации вроде нет, уь тоже нет, б мягкий

feature_title: Plural marker of the noun ‘son’
feature_description: The singular absolutive of the noun ‘son’ is *duχ*. The map shows the marker that is used in plural absolutive. The attested variants include: *-rä* (attested in Luchek and Kiche), *-ra* (in Ikhrek, Myukhrek, Dzhilikhur and Khnov) and *-re* (elsewhere).
name: Сара

feature_title: Plural marker of the noun ‘daughter’
feature_description: The singular absolutive of the noun ‘daughter’ is *rɨš*. The map shows the marker that is used in plural absolutive. The attested variants include:  *-ib* / *-ɨb* (Myukhrek and Dzhilikhur), *-bir*  (Khnov), *-bi* / *-bɨ* (Amsar), *-bä* / *-bäh* (Luchek) and *-be* (elsewhere).
name: Сара

feature_title: Plural marker of the noun ‘sister’
feature_description: The singular absolutive of the noun ‘sister’ is *riši*. The map shows the marker that is used in plural absolutive. The attested variants include: *-jma* (attested only in Khnov) and *-jmar* (elsewhere).
name: Сара

feature_description: The singular absolutive of the noun ‘daughter’ is *rɨš*. The map shows the marker that is used in plural absolutive. The attested variants include:  *-ib* / *-ɨb* (Myukhrek and Dzhilikhur), *-bir*  (Khnov), *-bi* / *-bɨ* (Amsar), *-bä* / *-bäh* (Luchek) and *-be* (elsewhere).

feature_title: Plural marker of the noun ‘brother’
feature_description: The singular absolutive of the noun ‘brother’ is either *šuˤ* (attested only in Khnov), *šugu* (attested only in Ikhrek) or *šu* (elsewhere). The attested variants of the plural marker include *-be* (and its phonetic variants) and *-jmar*. The latter forms either a simple — *šugu-jmar* (in Ikhrek), or a double marked plural — *šu-be-jmar* (and its phonetic variants). The map shows the distribution of the variants.
name: Алиса
comment: шубэ, б веляризованный? точно не палатализованный, уь в корне нету

feature_title: Plural marker of the noun ‘dog’
feature_description: The singular absolutive of the noun ‘dog’ is *tɨla* / *tala* and *χij* (only in Khnov). The map shows the marker that is used in plural absolutive. The attested variants include: *-jer* (attested in Dzhilikhur, Shinaz and from some speakers in Kina, Kala, Amsar), *-ʔir* / *-iːr* (attested only Ikhrek) and *-jmar* (elsewhere). In case of Khnov, due to distinct lexical item (*χij*) the value is labeled as OTHER.

feature_title: Phonetic variation in the noun ‘goat’
feature_description: The map shows phonetic variation in the absolutive singular of ‘goat’. The attested forms are *cʼihʲ* and *cʼij*.
name: Сара

feature_title: Plural of the noun ‘goat’
feature_description: The singular absolutive of the noun ‘goat’ is either *cʼihʲ* or *cʼij* (see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/028_Phonetic_variation_in_the_lexical_item_%E2%80%98goat%E2%80%99.html)). The plural absolutive can be either regular: *cʼiher*, *cʼihe* and *cʼijmar* (and their phonetic variants) or irregular: *cʼuhuler* (and its phonetic variants). Depending on the village, in our data only the regular forms are attested, only irregular ones, or both types of forms may coexist.
name: Сара
value: cʼuhuler / cʼuhulär / cʼɨhɨlar / cʼɨhɨler / cʼühüler / cʼuhular ; cʼiher / cʼihär / cʼeher

The plural absolutive can be either regular: *cʼiher*, *cʼihe* and *cʼijmar* (and their phonetic variants) or irregular: *cʼuhuler* (and its phonetic variants). Depending on the village, in our data only the regular forms are attested, only irregular ones, or both types of forms may coexist.
name: Саидмагомед
long_periods_outside: лет 30 жил в разных местах в России
comment: ц1угьулар - мелкий рогатый скот с шерстью

feature_title: Plural of objects coming in pairs
feature_description: Ibragimov [@ibragimov2004: 52, 126, 149, 152, 172] suggests that some dialects use special pluralization strategies for words denoting objects usually coming in pairs (eyes, legs, etc.). Such plurals are formed from singular absolutive (*ul* ‘eye’, *ʁil* ‘leg’) with formant *-ab*, e.g. *ulab* ‘eyes’, *ʁilab* ‘legs’. Other dialects have regular plurals, e.g. *ulabɨr* ‘eyes’, *ʁilabɨr* ‘legs’. We collected forms of these two nouns using three stimuli: ‘eyes’ (citation context), ‘She has beautiful eyes’ and ‘My legs hurt’. In the case of ‘eyes’, the first reaction always was the form *ulabɨr*. We asked whether the form *ulab* is possible. The map shows the results: **OK ulab** — the form *ulab* is possible, **NO ulab** — it is impossible. As for ‘leg’, we almost always got the form *ʁilabɨr* as the first reaction, except for Myukhrek, where the first reaction was *ʁilab* (but *ʁilabɨr* was also deemed possible). The map shows the results: **OK ʁilab** — the form *ʁilab* is possible, **NO ʁilab** — it is impossible, **ʁilab as first reaction** — a label for Myukhrek only, where, unlike other dialects, this form was the first reaction.
name: Сара

We collected forms of these two nouns using three stimuli: ‘eyes’ (citation context), ‘She has beautiful eyes’ and ‘My legs hurt’. In the case of ‘eyes’, the first reaction always was the form *ulabɨr*. We asked whether the form *ulab* is possible. The map shows the results: **OK ulab** — the form *ulab* is possible, **NO ulab** — it is impossible. As for ‘leg’, we almost always got the form *ʁilabɨr* as the first reaction, except for Myukhrek, where the first reaction was *ʁilab* (but *ʁilabɨr* was also deemed possible). The map shows the results: **OK ʁilab** — the form *ʁilab* is possible, **NO ʁilab** — it is impossible, **ʁilab as first reaction** — a label for Myukhrek only, where, unlike other dialects, this form was the first reaction.
name: Мухтар
long_periods_outside: 5 лет учился в городе, ездил по всей России на соревнования

feature_title: Plural of the noun ‘cow’
feature_description: The singular absolutive of the noun ‘cow’ varies as following: *zer*,  *zʲer*, *zär* and *zʲär* (see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/027_Phonetic_variation_in_the_lexical_item_%E2%80%98cow%E2%80%99.html)). The plural absolutive is irregular in that it loses /r/ of the root: *zebɨr* (and its phonetic variants: *zʲebɨr*, *zʲäbɨr*) and *zʲebir* / *zebir*. The map shows the variation in plural forms.
name: Сара

feature_title: Phonetic variation in the noun ‘cow’

feature_description: We elicited three contexts: ‘They cut down the trees’, ‘They built houses for themselves’, ‘They brought axes’. The maps show the plural marking on the nouns ‘tree’, ‘house’ and ‘axe’. The attested variants include: *-bɨ* (attested only in Khnov) and *-bɨr* (elsewhere).

feature_title: Associative plural marking
feature_description: A construction consisting of a noun X denoting human with an associative plural marker means ‘X and his associates (family, etc.)’. We elicited the context ‘Rasul's (family) came’. The map shows the associative plural marking on the noun ‘Rasul’. The attested variants include: *-ar*, *-quˁner* / *-quner*, *-qun* / *-quna*, *-qušdɨbɨr*, *-ašdɨbɨr* / *-ašidbɨ*, *-ašdɨ*,  *-dɨbɨr* / *-ɨdbɨ*, *-ɨbɨr*, *-(aš)dɨ bejdebɨr*.

The attested variants include: *-ar*, *-quˁner* / *-quner*, *-qun* / *-quna*, *-qušdɨbɨr*, *-ašdɨbɨr* / *-ašidbɨ*, *-ašdɨ*,  *-dɨbɨr* / *-ɨdbɨ*, *-ɨbɨr*, *-(aš)dɨ bejdebɨr*.

feature_title: Oblique stem ending in a sonorant
feature_description: We collected a set of 15 nouns with oblique stems in sonorant in attributive form. The maps show the sonorant that is present in an oblique stem formant: /r/ (value: R, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]), /l/ (value: L, e. g. *naʁ-ul-dɨ* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]), /j/ (value: J, e. g. *naʁ-uji-d* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]) or NO CONSONANT, if there is none.
name: Сара

feature_title: Oblique stem ending in a sonorant: presence of palatalization
feature_description: We collected a set of 15 nouns with oblique stems in sonorant in attributive form. We distinguish between soft and hard stems. Soft stems are morphophonologically palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with front vowels /e/, /i/ (value: SOFT, e. g. *ǯʷel-ir-dɨ* [sheaf-OBL-ATTR]). Hard stems are morphophonologically non-palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with non-front vowels /ɨ/, /a/ (value: HARD, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]). The maps show the variation in stem type.
name: Сара

The maps show the sonorant that is present in an oblique stem formant: /r/ (value: R, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]), /l/ (value: L, e. g. *naʁ-ul-dɨ* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]), /j/ (value: J, e. g. *naʁ-uji-d* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]) or NO CONSONANT, if there is none.
name: Айшат

feature_title: Oblique stem ending in a sonorant: presence of palatalization
feature_description: We collected a set of 15 nouns with oblique stems in sonorant in attributive form. We distinguish between soft and hard stems. Soft stems are morphophonologically palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with front vowels /e/, /i/ (value: SOFT, e. g. *ǯʷel-ir-dɨ* [sheaf-OBL-ATTR]). Hard stems are morphophonologically non-palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with non-front vowels /ɨ/, /a/ (value: HARD, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]). The maps show the variation in stem type.
name: Айшат

The maps show the sonorant that is present in an oblique stem formant: /r/ (value: R, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]), /l/ (value: L, e. g. *naʁ-ul-dɨ* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]), /j/ (value: J, e. g. *naʁ-uji-d* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]) or NO CONSONANT, if there is none.
name: Аризда

feature_title: Oblique stem ending in a sonorant: presence of palatalization
feature_description: We collected a set of 15 nouns with oblique stems in sonorant in attributive form. We distinguish between soft and hard stems. Soft stems are morphophonologically palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with front vowels /e/, /i/ (value: SOFT, e. g. *ǯʷel-ir-dɨ* [sheaf-OBL-ATTR]). Hard stems are morphophonologically non-palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with non-front vowels /ɨ/, /a/ (value: HARD, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]). The maps show the variation in stem type.
name: Аризда

feature_title: Oblique stem ending in a sonorant
feature_description: We collected a set of 15 nouns with oblique stems in sonorant in attributive form. The maps show the sonorant that is present in an oblique stem formant: /r/ (value: R, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]), /l/ (value: L, e. g. *naʁ-ul-dɨ* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]), /j/ (value: J, e. g. *naʁ-uji-d* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]) or NO CONSONANT, if there is none.
name: Набисат
schooling: 2 in Myukhrek, till 10th grade in Kalmykia

feature_description: We collected a set of 15 nouns with oblique stems in sonorant in attributive form. We distinguish between soft and hard stems. Soft stems are morphophonologically palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with front vowels /e/, /i/ (value: SOFT, e. g. *ǯʷel-ir-dɨ* [sheaf-OBL-ATTR]). Hard stems are morphophonologically non-palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with non-front vowels /ɨ/, /a/ (value: HARD, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]). The maps show the variation in stem type.
name: айша

feature_title: Oblique stem ending in a sonorant
feature_description: We collected a set of 15 nouns with oblique stems in sonorant in attributive form. feature_title: Oblique stem ending in a sonorant: presence of palatalization
feature_description: We collected a set of 15 nouns with oblique stems in sonorant in attributive form. We distinguish between soft and hard stems. Soft stems are morphophonologically palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with front vowels /e/, /i/ (value: SOFT, e. g. *ǯʷel-ir-dɨ* [sheaf-OBL-ATTR]). Hard stems are morphophonologically non-palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with non-front vowels /ɨ/, /a/ (value: HARD, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]). The maps show the variation in stem type.
name: x

Hard stems are morphophonologically non-palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with non-front vowels /ɨ/, /a/ (value: HARD, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]). The maps show the variation in stem type.
name: Тельман

feature_title: Oblique stem ending in a sonorant
feature_description: We collected a set of 15 nouns with oblique stems in sonorant in attributive form. The maps show the sonorant that is present in an oblique stem formant: /r/ (value: R, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]), /l/ (value: L, e. g. *naʁ-ul-dɨ* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]), /j/ (value: J, e. g. *naʁ-uji-d* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]) or NO CONSONANT, if there is none.
name: Тельман

The maps show the sonorant that is present in an oblique stem formant: /r/ (value: R, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]), /l/ (value: L, e. g. *naʁ-ul-dɨ* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]), /j/ (value: J, e. g. *naʁ-uji-d* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]) or NO CONSONANT, if there is none.
name: эмираслан
long_periods_outside: ездит из города сюда, больше в селе жил

feature_title: Oblique stem ending in a sonorant: presence of palatalization
feature_description: We collected a set of 15 nouns with oblique stems in sonorant in attributive form. We distinguish between soft and hard stems. Soft stems are morphophonologically palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with front vowels /e/, /i/ (value: SOFT, e. g. *ǯʷel-ir-dɨ* [sheaf-OBL-ATTR]). Hard stems are morphophonologically non-palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with non-front vowels /ɨ/, /a/ (value: HARD, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]). The maps show the variation in stem type.
name: эмираслан
long_periods_outside: ездит из города сюда, больше в селе жил

Soft stems are morphophonologically palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with front vowels /e/, /i/ (value: SOFT, e. g. *ǯʷel-ir-dɨ* [sheaf-OBL-ATTR]). Hard stems are morphophonologically non-palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with non-front vowels /ɨ/, /a/ (value: HARD, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]). The maps show the variation in stem type.
name: Феруза

feature_title: Oblique stem ending in a sonorant
feature_description: We collected a set of 15 nouns with oblique stems in sonorant in attributive form. The maps show the sonorant that is present in an oblique stem formant: /r/ (value: R, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]), /l/ (value: L, e. g. *naʁ-ul-dɨ* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]), /j/ (value: J, e. g. *naʁ-uji-d* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]) or NO CONSONANT, if there is none.
name: Хева

The maps show the sonorant that is present in an oblique stem formant: /r/ (value: R, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]), /l/ (value: L, e. g. *naʁ-ul-dɨ* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]), /j/ (value: J, e. g. *naʁ-uji-d* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]) or NO CONSONANT, if there is none.
name: Мехти

feature_title: Oblique stem ending in a sonorant: presence of palatalization
feature_description: We collected a set of 15 nouns with oblique stems in sonorant in attributive form. We distinguish between soft and hard stems. Soft stems are morphophonologically palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with front vowels /e/, /i/ (value: SOFT, e. g. *ǯʷel-ir-dɨ* [sheaf-OBL-ATTR]). Hard stems are morphophonologically non-palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with non-front vowels /ɨ/, /a/ (value: HARD, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]). The maps show the variation in stem type.
name: Мехти

Soft stems are morphophonologically palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with front vowels /e/, /i/ (value: SOFT, e. g. *ǯʷel-ir-dɨ* [sheaf-OBL-ATTR]). Hard stems are morphophonologically non-palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with non-front vowels /ɨ/, /a/ (value: HARD, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]). The maps show the variation in stem type.
name: айваз
residence_place: c 1982 года в Рутуле — после окончания института

feature_title: Oblique stem ending in a sonorant
feature_description: We collected a set of 15 nouns with oblique stems in sonorant in attributive form. The maps show the sonorant that is present in an oblique stem formant: /r/ (value: R, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]), /l/ (value: L, e. g. *naʁ-ul-dɨ* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]), /j/ (value: J, e. g. *naʁ-uji-d* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]) or NO CONSONANT, if there is none.
name: рамин

feature_description: We collected a set of 15 nouns with oblique stems in sonorant in attributive form. The maps show the sonorant that is present in an oblique stem formant: /r/ (value: R, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]), /l/ (value: L, e. g. *naʁ-ul-dɨ* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]), /j/ (value: J, e. g. *naʁ-uji-d* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]) or NO CONSONANT, if there is none.
name: муратхан
residence_place: сейчас в Каспийске — после школы, приезжает в куфа

feature_title: Oblique stem ending in a sonorant: presence of palatalization
feature_description: We collected a set of 15 nouns with oblique stems in sonorant in attributive form. We distinguish between soft and hard stems. Soft stems are morphophonologically palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with front vowels /e/, /i/ (value: SOFT, e. g. *ǯʷel-ir-dɨ* [sheaf-OBL-ATTR]). Hard stems are morphophonologically non-palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with non-front vowels /ɨ/, /a/ (value: HARD, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]). The maps show the variation in stem type.
name: муратхан

The maps show the sonorant that is present in an oblique stem formant: /r/ (value: R, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]), /l/ (value: L, e. g. *naʁ-ul-dɨ* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]), /j/ (value: J, e. g. *naʁ-uji-d* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]) or NO CONSONANT, if there is none.
name: Али

feature_title: Oblique stem ending in a sonorant: presence of palatalization
feature_description: We collected a set of 15 nouns with oblique stems in sonorant in attributive form. We distinguish between soft and hard stems. Soft stems are morphophonologically palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with front vowels /e/, /i/ (value: SOFT, e. g. *ǯʷel-ir-dɨ* [sheaf-OBL-ATTR]). Hard stems are morphophonologically non-palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with non-front vowels /ɨ/, /a/ (value: HARD, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]). The maps show the variation in stem type.
name: Али

Hard stems are morphophonologically non-palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with non-front vowels /ɨ/, /a/ (value: HARD, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]). The maps show the variation in stem type.
name: Нурулла

feature_title: Oblique stem ending in a sonorant
feature_description: We collected a set of 15 nouns with oblique stems in sonorant in attributive form. The maps show the sonorant that is present in an oblique stem formant: /r/ (value: R, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]), /l/ (value: L, e. g. *naʁ-ul-dɨ* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]), /j/ (value: J, e. g. *naʁ-uji-d* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]) or NO CONSONANT, if there is none.

The maps show the sonorant that is present in an oblique stem formant: /r/ (value: R, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]), /l/ (value: L, e. g. *naʁ-ul-dɨ* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]), /j/ (value: J, e. g. *naʁ-uji-d* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]) or NO CONSONANT, if there is none.
name: Сабир

feature_title: Oblique stem ending in a sonorant: presence of palatalization
feature_description: We collected a set of 15 nouns with oblique stems in sonorant in attributive form. We distinguish between soft and hard stems. Soft stems are morphophonologically palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with front vowels /e/, /i/ (value: SOFT, e. g. *ǯʷel-ir-dɨ* [sheaf-OBL-ATTR]). Hard stems are morphophonologically non-palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with non-front vowels /ɨ/, /a/ (value: HARD, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]). The maps show the variation in stem type.
name: Сабир

The maps show the sonorant that is present in an oblique stem formant: /r/ (value: R, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]), /l/ (value: L, e. g. *naʁ-ul-dɨ* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]), /j/ (value: J, e. g. *naʁ-uji-d* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]) or NO CONSONANT, if there is none.
name: Альфина
residence_place: Makhachkala, но дома говорят всегда по-хновски, хорошо знает язык

feature_title: Oblique stem ending in a sonorant: presence of palatalization
feature_description: We collected a set of 15 nouns with oblique stems in sonorant in attributive form. We distinguish between soft and hard stems. Soft stems are morphophonologically palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with front vowels /e/, /i/ (value: SOFT, e. g. *ǯʷel-ir-dɨ* [sheaf-OBL-ATTR]). Hard stems are morphophonologically non-palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with non-front vowels /ɨ/, /a/ (value: HARD, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]). The maps show the variation in stem type.
name: Альфина
residence_place: Makhachkala, но дома говорят всегда по-хновски, хорошо знает язык

Hard stems are morphophonologically non-palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with non-front vowels /ɨ/, /a/ (value: HARD, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]). The maps show the variation in stem type.
name: Ахмад
long_periods_outside: в 16 лет переехал в Махачкалу, каждый год приезжает, до 21 года в Москве жил

feature_title: Oblique stem ending in a sonorant
feature_description: We collected a set of 15 nouns with oblique stems in sonorant in attributive form. The maps show the sonorant that is present in an oblique stem formant: /r/ (value: R, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]), /l/ (value: L, e. g. *naʁ-ul-dɨ* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]), /j/ (value: J, e. g. *naʁ-uji-d* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]) or NO CONSONANT, if there is none.

Hard stems are morphophonologically non-palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with non-front vowels /ɨ/, /a/ (value: HARD, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]). The maps show the variation in stem type.
name: Феруза

feature_title: Oblique stem ending in a sonorant
feature_description: We collected a set of 15 nouns with oblique stems in sonorant in attributive form. The maps show the sonorant that is present in an oblique stem formant: /r/ (value: R, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]), /l/ (value: L, e. g. *naʁ-ul-dɨ* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]), /j/ (value: J, e. g. *naʁ-uji-d* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]) or NO CONSONANT, if there is none.
name: Феруза

The maps show the sonorant that is present in an oblique stem formant: /r/ (value: R, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]), /l/ (value: L, e. g. *naʁ-ul-dɨ* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]), /j/ (value: J, e. g. *naʁ-uji-d* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]) or NO CONSONANT, if there is none.
name: Мехти

feature_title: Oblique stem ending in a sonorant: presence of palatalization
feature_description: We collected a set of 15 nouns with oblique stems in sonorant in attributive form. We distinguish between soft and hard stems. Soft stems are morphophonologically palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with front vowels /e/, /i/ (value: SOFT, e. g. *ǯʷel-ir-dɨ* [sheaf-OBL-ATTR]). Hard stems are morphophonologically non-palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with non-front vowels /ɨ/, /a/ (value: HARD, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]). The maps show the variation in stem type.
name: Мехти

The maps show the sonorant that is present in an oblique stem formant: /r/ (value: R, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]), /l/ (value: L, e. g. *naʁ-ul-dɨ* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]), /j/ (value: J, e. g. *naʁ-uji-d* [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]) or NO CONSONANT, if there is none.
name: Муслимат
long_periods_outside: в Махачкале закончила университет - филологический факультет

feature_title: Oblique stem ending in a sonorant: presence of palatalization
feature_description: We collected a set of 15 nouns with oblique stems in sonorant in attributive form. We distinguish between soft and hard stems. Soft stems are morphophonologically palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with front vowels /e/, /i/ (value: SOFT, e. g. *ǯʷel-ir-dɨ* [sheaf-OBL-ATTR]). Hard stems are morphophonologically non-palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with non-front vowels /ɨ/, /a/ (value: HARD, e. g. *git-ɨr-dɨ* [cat-OBL-ATTR]). The maps show the variation in stem type.
name: Муслимат
long_periods_outside: в Махачкале закончила университет - филологический факультет

feature_title: Ergative marker type of the singular attributive
feature_description: Likewise to nouns (see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/004_Ergative_marker_type.html)), we classified the variants of the ergative marker of attributives into r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nu-ra* [lame-OBL-ERG]) and non-r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* [lame-OBL-ERG], *alkʼa-now-Ø* [lame-OBL-ERG]). We elicited three attributives referring to humans: ‘tall’, ‘short’ and ‘lame’. The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. The maps show the type (r-type or non-r-type) of the ergative marker used in each of the attributives, respectively.
name: Сара
stimuli: [Пришло два человека:] Высокий собирал яблоки, а низкий держал лестницу
comment: ху1л'ахнов (можно ды), джик'дынов, без ды нельзя

feature_title: Presence of the vowel in the ergative of the singular attributive form
feature_description:
The ergative marker of attributives may be of r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nu-ra* [lame-OBL-ERG]) or of non-r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* [lame-OBL-ERG], *alkʼa-now-Ø* [lame-OBL-ERG]), see [feature](). It may either contain (*alkʼa-nu-ra* [lame-OBL-ERG], *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* [lame-OBL-ERG]) or lack (*alkʼa-nu-r* [lame-OBL-ERG], *alkʼa-now-Ø* [lame-OBL-ERG]) the final vowel. The feature considers the first reaction, and second reaction was not collected. We elicited three attributives referring to humans: ‘tall’, ‘short’ and ‘lame’. The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.

N. B. In Shinaz it is considered that vowel in non-r-type ergative marker is ABSENT, because the oblique stem formant is *-na-* (cf. dative case form *kʼaʔa-dɨ-na-s* [little-ATTR-OBL-DAT] and also see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/025_Oblique_stem_formant_of_attributive_in_ergative_singular.html)), that is, there is no evident ergative marker.

answer: harχɨnɨwɨ, ǯikʲdɨnɨwɨ, OK ǯikʲnɨwɨ, OK ǯikʲdɨnɨw
comment: можно джик'нывы - без -ды-, можно без -ы на конце

feature_title: Oblique stem of the attributive form in the ergative singular
feature_description: The maps show how the oblique stem of attributive referring to humans is formed. We asked two contexts with three attributives: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. Three variants of stem formants are attested: *-nij* / *-ni* (in Rutul, Kufa, Kiche and Kala), *-na* (in Shinaz and Khnov) and *-naw* / *-now* / *-nɨw* / *-nu* (elsewhere). For example, for the form *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* [lame-OBL-ERG], cf. with absolutive form *alkʼa-d* [lame-ATTR], the formant *-nɨw* is used to form an oblique stem.
name: Али
stimuli: [Пришло два человека:] Высокий собирал яблоки, а низкий держал лестницу
answer: harχɨnɨwɨ, ǯikʲdɨnɨwɨ, OK ǯikʲnɨwɨ, OK ǯikʲdɨnɨw
comment: можно джик'нывы - без -ды-, можно без -ы на конце

feature_title: Ergative marker type of the singular attributive
feature_description: Likewise to nouns (see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/004_Ergative_marker_type.html)), we classified the variants of the ergative marker of attributives into r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nu-ra* [lame-OBL-ERG]) and non-r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* [lame-OBL-ERG], *alkʼa-now-Ø* [lame-OBL-ERG]). We elicited three attributives referring to humans: ‘tall’, ‘short’ and ‘lame’. The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. The maps show the type (r-type or non-r-type) of the ergative marker used in each of the attributives, respectively.
name: Али
comment: конечное ы временами падает, но вставить обратно можно

feature_title: Presence of the vowel in the ergative of the singular attributive form
feature_description:
The ergative marker of attributives may be of r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nu-ra* [lame-OBL-ERG]) or of non-r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* [lame-OBL-ERG], *alkʼa-now-Ø* [lame-OBL-ERG]), see [feature](). It may either contain (*alkʼa-nu-ra* [lame-OBL-ERG], *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* [lame-OBL-ERG]) or lack (*alkʼa-nu-r* [lame-OBL-ERG], *alkʼa-now-Ø* [lame-OBL-ERG]) the final vowel. The feature considers the first reaction, and second reaction was not collected. We elicited three attributives referring to humans: ‘tall’, ‘short’ and ‘lame’. The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.

N. B. In Shinaz it is considered that vowel in non-r-type ergative marker is ABSENT, because the oblique stem formant is *-na-* (cf. dative case form *kʼaʔa-dɨ-na-s* [little-ATTR-OBL-DAT] and also see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/025_Oblique_stem_formant_of_attributive_in_ergative_singular.html)), that is, there is no evident ergative marker.
name: Али
comment: конечное ы временами падает, но вставить обратно можно

It may either contain (*alkʼa-nu-ra* [lame-OBL-ERG], *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* [lame-OBL-ERG]) or lack (*alkʼa-nu-r* [lame-OBL-ERG], *alkʼa-now-Ø* [lame-OBL-ERG]) the final vowel. The feature considers the first reaction, and second reaction was not collected. We elicited three attributives referring to humans: ‘tall’, ‘short’ and ‘lame’. The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.

N. B. In Shinaz it is considered that vowel in non-r-type ergative marker is ABSENT, because the oblique stem formant is *-na-* (cf. dative case form *kʼaʔa-dɨ-na-s* [little-ATTR-OBL-DAT] and also see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/025_Oblique_stem_formant_of_attributive_in_ergative_singular.html)), that is, there is no evident ergative marker.

feature_description: Likewise to nouns (see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/004_Ergative_marker_type.html)), we classified the variants of the ergative marker of attributives into r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nu-ra* [lame-OBL-ERG]) and non-r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* [lame-OBL-ERG], *alkʼa-now-Ø* [lame-OBL-ERG]). We elicited three attributives referring to humans: ‘tall’, ‘short’ and ‘lame’. The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. The maps show the type (r-type or non-r-type) of the ergative marker used in each of the attributives, respectively.
name: муслимат
stimuli: [Пришло два человека:] Высокий собирал яблоки, а низкий держал лестницу

feature_title: Presence of the vowel in the ergative of the singular attributive form
feature_description:
The ergative marker of attributives may be of r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nu-ra* [lame-OBL-ERG]) or of non-r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* [lame-OBL-ERG], *alkʼa-now-Ø* [lame-OBL-ERG]), see [feature](). It may either contain (*alkʼa-nu-ra* [lame-OBL-ERG], *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* [lame-OBL-ERG]) or lack (*alkʼa-nu-r* [lame-OBL-ERG], *alkʼa-now-Ø* [lame-OBL-ERG]) the final vowel. The feature considers the first reaction, and second reaction was not collected. We elicited three attributives referring to humans: ‘tall’, ‘short’ and ‘lame’. The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.

N. B. In Shinaz it is considered that vowel in non-r-type ergative marker is ABSENT, because the oblique stem formant is *-na-* (cf. dative case form *kʼaʔa-dɨ-na-s* [little-ATTR-OBL-DAT] and also see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/025_Oblique_stem_formant_of_attributive_in_ergative_singular.html)), that is, there is no evident ergative marker.

feature_title: Oblique stem of the attributive form in the ergative singular
feature_description: The maps show how the oblique stem of attributive referring to humans is formed. We asked two contexts with three attributives: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. Three variants of stem formants are attested: *-nij* / *-ni* (in Rutul, Kufa, Kiche and Kala), *-na* (in Shinaz and Khnov) and *-naw* / *-now* / *-nɨw* / *-nu* (elsewhere). For example, for the form *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* [lame-OBL-ERG], cf. with absolutive form *alkʼa-d* [lame-ATTR], the formant *-nɨw* is used to form an oblique stem.

feature_title: Presence of the vowel in the ergative of the singular attributive form
feature_description:
The ergative marker of attributives may be of r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nu-ra* [lame-OBL-ERG]) or of non-r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* [lame-OBL-ERG], *alkʼa-now-Ø* [lame-OBL-ERG]), see [feature](). It may either contain (*alkʼa-nu-ra* [lame-OBL-ERG], *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* [lame-OBL-ERG]) or lack (*alkʼa-nu-r* [lame-OBL-ERG], *alkʼa-now-Ø* [lame-OBL-ERG]) the final vowel. The feature considers the first reaction, and second reaction was not collected. We elicited three attributives referring to humans: ‘tall’, ‘short’ and ‘lame’. The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.

N. B. In Shinaz it is considered that vowel in non-r-type ergative marker is ABSENT, because the oblique stem formant is *-na-* (cf. dative case form *kʼaʔa-dɨ-na-s* [little-ATTR-OBL-DAT] and also see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/025_Oblique_stem_formant_of_attributive_in_ergative_singular.html)), that is, there is no evident ergative marker.
name: x
mothers_birthplace: Джилихур мама — тухум dašla; у папы тот же тухум, они родственники; четвероюродные
stimuli: [Пришло два человека:] Высокий собирал яблоки, а низкий держал лестницу

feature_title: Oblique stem of the attributive form in the ergative singular
feature_description: The maps show how the oblique stem of attributive referring to humans is formed. We asked two contexts with three attributives: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. Three variants of stem formants are attested: *-nij* / *-ni* (in Rutul, Kufa, Kiche and Kala), *-na* (in Shinaz and Khnov) and *-naw* / *-now* / *-nɨw* / *-nu* (elsewhere). For example, for the form *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* [lame-OBL-ERG], cf. with absolutive form *alkʼa-d* [lame-ATTR], the formant *-nɨw* is used to form an oblique stem.

It may either contain (*alkʼa-nu-ra* [lame-OBL-ERG], *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* [lame-OBL-ERG]) or lack (*alkʼa-nu-r* [lame-OBL-ERG], *alkʼa-now-Ø* [lame-OBL-ERG]) the final vowel. The feature considers the first reaction, and second reaction was not collected. We elicited three attributives referring to humans: ‘tall’, ‘short’ and ‘lame’. The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.

N. B. In Shinaz it is considered that vowel in non-r-type ergative marker is ABSENT, because the oblique stem formant is *-na-* (cf. dative case form *kʼaʔa-dɨ-na-s* [little-ATTR-OBL-DAT] and also see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/025_Oblique_stem_formant_of_attributive_in_ergative_singular.html)), that is, there is no evident ergative marker.

The feature considers the first reaction, and second reaction was not collected. We elicited three attributives referring to humans: ‘tall’, ‘short’ and ‘lame’. The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.

N. B. In Shinaz it is considered that vowel in non-r-type ergative marker is ABSENT, because the oblique stem formant is *-na-* (cf. dative case form *kʼaʔa-dɨ-na-s* [little-ATTR-OBL-DAT] and also see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/025_Oblique_stem_formant_of_attributive_in_ergative_singular.html)), that is, there is no evident ergative marker.

The maps show the type (r-type or non-r-type) of the ergative marker used in each of the attributives, respectively.

The feature considers the first reaction, and second reaction was not collected. We elicited three attributives referring to humans: ‘tall’, ‘short’ and ‘lame’. The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. In Shinaz it is considered that vowel in non-r-type ergative marker is ABSENT, because the oblique stem formant is *-na-* (cf. dative case form *kʼaʔa-dɨ-na-s* [little-ATTR-OBL-DAT] and also see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/025_Oblique_stem_formant_of_attributive_in_ergative_singular.html)), that is, there is no evident ergative marker.

For example, for the form *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* [lame-OBL-ERG], cf. with absolutive form *alkʼa-d* [lame-ATTR], the formant *-nɨw* is used to form an oblique stem.
name: муратхан
residence_place: сейчас в Каспийске — после школы, приезжает в куфа
stimuli: [Пришло два человека:] Высокий собирал яблоки, а низкий держал лестницу

feature_title: Ergative marker type of the singular attributive
feature_description: Likewise to nouns (see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/004_Ergative_marker_type.html)), we classified the variants of the ergative marker of attributives into r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nu-ra* [lame-OBL-ERG]) and non-r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* [lame-OBL-ERG], *alkʼa-now-Ø* [lame-OBL-ERG]). We elicited three attributives referring to humans: ‘tall’, ‘short’ and ‘lame’. The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. The maps show the type (r-type or non-r-type) of the ergative marker used in each of the attributives, respectively.
name: муратхан
residence_place: сейчас в Каспийске — после школы, приезжает в куфа
stimuli: [Пришло два человека:] Высокий собирал яблоки, а низкий держал лестницу

feature_title: Presence of the vowel in the ergative of the singular attributive form
feature_description:
The ergative marker of attributives may be of r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nu-ra* [lame-OBL-ERG]) or of non-r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* [lame-OBL-ERG], *alkʼa-now-Ø* [lame-OBL-ERG]), see [feature](). It may either contain (*alkʼa-nu-ra* [lame-OBL-ERG], *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* [lame-OBL-ERG]) or lack (*alkʼa-nu-r* [lame-OBL-ERG], *alkʼa-now-Ø* [lame-OBL-ERG]) the final vowel. The feature considers the first reaction, and second reaction was not collected. We elicited three attributives referring to humans: ‘tall’, ‘short’ and ‘lame’. The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.

N. B. In Shinaz it is considered that vowel in non-r-type ergative marker is ABSENT, because the oblique stem formant is *-na-* (cf. dative case form *kʼaʔa-dɨ-na-s* [little-ATTR-OBL-DAT] and also see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/025_Oblique_stem_formant_of_attributive_in_ergative_singular.html)), that is, there is no evident ergative marker.
name: муратхан
residence_place: сейчас в Каспийске — после школы, приезжает в куфа
stimuli: [Пришло два человека:] Высокий собирал яблоки, а низкий держал лестницу

feature_title: Oblique stem of the attributive form in the ergative singular
feature_description: The maps show how the oblique stem of attributive referring to humans is formed. We asked two contexts with three attributives: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. Three variants of stem formants are attested: *-nij* / *-ni* (in Rutul, Kufa, Kiche and Kala), *-na* (in Shinaz and Khnov) and *-naw* / *-now* / *-nɨw* / *-nu* (elsewhere). For example, for the form *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* [lame-OBL-ERG], cf. with absolutive form *alkʼa-d* [lame-ATTR], the formant *-nɨw* is used to form an oblique stem.

residence_place: сейчас в Каспийске — после школы, приезжает в куфа
stimuli: [Пришло два человека:] Высокий собирал яблоки, а низкий держал лестницу

feature_title: Ergative marker type
feature_description: We classified the variants of the ergative marker into r-type (e.g. *balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG]) and non-r-type (e.g. *gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]). We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the type (r-type or non-r-type) of the ergative marker used in each of the contexts, respectively.
name: Сара

feature_title: Ergative marker: presence of vowel
feature_description: Ergative marker may be of r-type (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG]) or non-r-type (*gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]), see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/004_Ergative_marker_type.html). Apart from that, it may either contain (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG]) or lack (*balʁu-r* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]) final vowel. This feature considers the first reaction to the stimuli, for the second reaction, i.e. the possibility of an alternative form, see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/007_Ergative_marker_vowel_presence_variation.html). We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). feature_description: We classified the variants of the ergative marker into r-type (e.g. *balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG]) and non-r-type (e.g. *gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]). We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the type (r-type or non-r-type) of the ergative marker used in each of the contexts, respectively.
name: Али

Apart from that, it may either contain (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG]) or lack (*balʁu-r* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]) final vowel. For the presence of vowel in the first reaction, see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/006_Ergative_marker_vowel_presence.html). This feature shows whether an alternative to the first reaction is also possible in terms of vocalic vs. non-vocalic ergative marker. For example, if the speaker's first reaction was *balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG], we asked if it is possible to say *balʁu-r*, and vice versa. If the alternative variant is possible, we report variation. We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show whether variation between vocalic ergative marker vs. non-vocalic ergative marker is attested.
name: Кавказ

feature_title: Ergative marker type
feature_description: We classified the variants of the ergative marker into r-type (e.g. *balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG]) and non-r-type (e.g. *gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]). We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the type (r-type or non-r-type) of the ergative marker used in each of the contexts, respectively.
name: Кавказ

The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the type (r-type or non-r-type) of the ergative marker used in each of the contexts, respectively.
name: Аризда

feature_description: Ergative marker may be of r-type (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG]) or non-r-type (*gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]), see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/004_Ergative_marker_type.html). Apart from that, it may either contain (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG]) or lack (*balʁu-r* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]) final vowel. For the presence of vowel in the first reaction, see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/006_Ergative_marker_vowel_presence.html). This feature shows whether an alternative to the first reaction is also possible in terms of vocalic vs. non-vocalic ergative marker. For example, if the speaker's first reaction was *balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG], we asked if it is possible to say *balʁu-r*, and vice versa. If the alternative variant is possible, we report variation. We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show whether variation between vocalic ergative marker vs. non-vocalic ergative marker is attested.

The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the type (r-type or non-r-type) of the ergative marker used in each of the contexts, respectively.

Apart from that, it may either contain (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG]) or lack (*balʁu-r* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]) final vowel. For the presence of vowel in the first reaction, see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/006_Ergative_marker_vowel_presence.html). This feature shows whether an alternative to the first reaction is also possible in terms of vocalic vs. non-vocalic ergative marker. For example, if the speaker's first reaction was *balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG], we asked if it is possible to say *balʁu-r*, and vice versa. If the alternative variant is possible, we report variation. We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show whether variation between vocalic ergative marker vs. non-vocalic ergative marker is attested.
name: айша

feature_title: Ergative marker type
feature_description: We classified the variants of the ergative marker into r-type (e.g. *balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG]) and non-r-type (e.g. *gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]). We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the type (r-type or non-r-type) of the ergative marker used in each of the contexts, respectively.

name: спартак
mothers_birthplace: мама — Джилихур, тухум Дашлай; папа — Джилихур, тухум Джамалы
answer: duχlir čardaχ qʼad wɨʔɨra, OK duχlira čardaχ qʼad wɨʔɨra

feature_title: Ergative marker: presence of vowel
feature_description: Ergative marker may be of r-type (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG]) or non-r-type (*gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]), see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/004_Ergative_marker_type.html). Apart from that, it may either contain (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG]) or lack (*balʁu-r* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]) final vowel. This feature considers the first reaction to the stimuli, for the second reaction, i.e. the possibility of an alternative form, see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/007_Ergative_marker_vowel_presence_variation.html). We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.
name: спартак
mothers_birthplace: мама — Джилихур, тухум Дашлай; папа — Джилихур, тухум Джамалы
answer: duχlir čardaχ qʼad wɨʔɨra, OK duχlira čardaχ qʼad wɨʔɨra

feature_title: Ergative marker: variation in the presence of vowel
feature_description: Ergative marker may be of r-type (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG]) or non-r-type (*gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]), see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/004_Ergative_marker_type.html). Apart from that, it may either contain (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG]) or lack (*balʁu-r* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]) final vowel. For the presence of vowel in the first reaction, see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/006_Ergative_marker_vowel_presence.html). This feature shows whether an alternative to the first reaction is also possible in terms of vocalic vs. non-vocalic ergative marker. For example, if the speaker's first reaction was *balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG], we asked if it is possible to say *balʁu-r*, and vice versa. If the alternative variant is possible, we report variation. We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show whether variation between vocalic ergative marker vs. non-vocalic ergative marker is attested.

feature_title: Ergative marker type
feature_description: We classified the variants of the ergative marker into r-type (e.g. *balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG]) and non-r-type (e.g. *gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]). We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the type (r-type or non-r-type) of the ergative marker used in each of the contexts, respectively.

Apart from that, it may either contain (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG]) or lack (*balʁu-r* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]) final vowel. For the presence of vowel in the first reaction, see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/006_Ergative_marker_vowel_presence.html). This feature shows whether an alternative to the first reaction is also possible in terms of vocalic vs. non-vocalic ergative marker. For example, if the speaker's first reaction was *balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG], we asked if it is possible to say *balʁu-r*, and vice versa. If the alternative variant is possible, we report variation. We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show whether variation between vocalic ergative marker vs. non-vocalic ergative marker is attested.
name: урусбек

feature_title: Ergative marker type

We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the type (r-type or non-r-type) of the ergative marker used in each of the contexts, respectively.

This feature considers the first reaction to the stimuli, for the second reaction, i.e. the possibility of an alternative form, see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/007_Ergative_marker_vowel_presence_variation.html). We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.

feature_description: Ergative marker may be of r-type (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG]) or non-r-type (*gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]), see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/004_Ergative_marker_type.html). Apart from that, it may either contain (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG]) or lack (*balʁu-r* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]) final vowel. This feature considers the first reaction to the stimuli, for the second reaction, i.e. the possibility of an alternative form, see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/007_Ergative_marker_vowel_presence_variation.html). We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.
name: Ахмад
long_periods_outside: в 16 лет переехал в Махачкалу, каждый год приезжает, до 21 года в Москве жил

feature_description: We classified the variants of the ergative marker into r-type (e.g. *balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG]) and non-r-type (e.g. *gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]). We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the type (r-type or non-r-type) of the ergative marker used in each of the contexts, respectively.
name: эмираслан
long_periods_outside: ездит из города сюда, больше в селе жил

feature_title: Ergative marker: presence of vowel
feature_description: Ergative marker may be of r-type (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG]) or non-r-type (*gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]), see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/004_Ergative_marker_type.html). Apart from that, it may either contain (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG]) or lack (*balʁu-r* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]) final vowel. This feature considers the first reaction to the stimuli, for the second reaction, i.e. the possibility of an alternative form, see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/007_Ergative_marker_vowel_presence_variation.html). We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.

feature_title: Ergative marker: variation in the presence of vowel
feature_description: Ergative marker may be of r-type (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG]) or non-r-type (*gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]), see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/004_Ergative_marker_type.html). Apart from that, it may either contain (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG]) or lack (*balʁu-r* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]) final vowel. For the presence of vowel in the first reaction, see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/006_Ergative_marker_vowel_presence.html). This feature shows whether an alternative to the first reaction is also possible in terms of vocalic vs. non-vocalic ergative marker. For example, if the speaker's first reaction was *balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG], we asked if it is possible to say *balʁu-r*, and vice versa. If the alternative variant is possible, we report variation. We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show whether variation between vocalic ergative marker vs. non-vocalic ergative marker is attested.
name: Фарида
answer: ugajmaše kumag wɨʔɨr χal haʔas, OK ugajmaš

feature_description: We classified the variants of the ergative marker into r-type (e.g. *balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG]) and non-r-type (e.g. *gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]). We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the type (r-type or non-r-type) of the ergative marker used in each of the contexts, respectively.
name: Феруза
answer: dʲadijmaše kumag wɨʔɨr χala as, OK dʲadijmaš

feature_title: Ergative marker: presence of vowel
feature_description: Ergative marker may be of r-type (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG]) or non-r-type (*gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]), see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/004_Ergative_marker_type.html). Apart from that, it may either contain (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG]) or lack (*balʁu-r* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]) final vowel. The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.

Apart from that, it may either contain (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG]) or lack (*balʁu-r* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]) final vowel. This feature considers the first reaction to the stimuli, for the second reaction, i.e. the possibility of an alternative form, see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/007_Ergative_marker_vowel_presence_variation.html). We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.
name: Хева

feature_title: Ergative marker: variation in the presence of vowel
feature_description: Ergative marker may be of r-type (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG]) or non-r-type (*gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]), see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/004_Ergative_marker_type.html). Apart from that, it may either contain (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG]) or lack (*balʁu-r* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]) final vowel. For the presence of vowel in the first reaction, see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/006_Ergative_marker_vowel_presence.html). This feature shows whether an alternative to the first reaction is also possible in terms of vocalic vs. non-vocalic ergative marker. For example, if the speaker's first reaction was *balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG], we asked if it is possible to say *balʁu-r*, and vice versa. If the alternative variant is possible, we report variation. We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show whether variation between vocalic ergative marker vs. non-vocalic ergative marker is attested.
name: Хева

We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The maps show whether variation between vocalic ergative marker vs. non-vocalic ergative marker is attested.

For the presence of vowel in the first reaction, see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/006_Ergative_marker_vowel_presence.html). This feature shows whether an alternative to the first reaction is also possible in terms of vocalic vs. non-vocalic ergative marker. For example, if the speaker's first reaction was *balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG], we asked if it is possible to say *balʁu-r*, and vice versa. If the alternative variant is possible, we report variation. We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show whether variation between vocalic ergative marker vs. non-vocalic ergative marker is attested.
name: Индира

We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the type (r-type or non-r-type) of the ergative marker used in each of the contexts, respectively.
name: Марита

feature_title: Ergative marker: presence of vowel
feature_description: Ergative marker may be of r-type (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG]) or non-r-type (*gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]), see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/004_Ergative_marker_type.html). Apart from that, it may either contain (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG]) or lack (*balʁu-r* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]) final vowel. This feature considers the first reaction to the stimuli, for the second reaction, i.e. the possibility of an alternative form, see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/007_Ergative_marker_vowel_presence_variation.html). We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.

This feature considers the first reaction to the stimuli, for the second reaction, i.e. the possibility of an alternative form, see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/007_Ergative_marker_vowel_presence_variation.html). We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.

feature_description: Ergative marker may be of r-type (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG]) or non-r-type (*gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]), see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/004_Ergative_marker_type.html). Apart from that, it may either contain (*balʁu-ra* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-e* [uncle-ERG]) or lack (*balʁu-r* [fish.OBL-ERG], *gagaj-Ø* [uncle-ERG]) final vowel. This feature considers the first reaction to the stimuli, for the second reaction, i.e. the possibility of an alternative form, see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/007_Ergative_marker_vowel_presence_variation.html). We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.

feature_title: Comitative marker
feature_description: The maps show the variation of the comitative marker as represented in two elicited contexts: ‘Rasul went hunting with a dog’ and ‘Rasul went to Makhachkala by car’. The markers attested are the following: *-kʷan*, *-kan*, *-xʷan*, *-xan*, *-fan*. The variants *-kʷan* and *-kan* are attested in Kina, Luchek, Amsar and Kiche, *-fan* is attested in Ikhrek and Khnov, *-xan* is attested in Ikhrek and Rutul. The last variant, *-xʷan* is attested everywhere except Kina, Luchek and Khnov. The label OTHER is used if the meaning is expressed by means other than a nominal suffix but by a construction with a locative copula: *χana*, *χan*, *xʷana*.
name: Сара
stimuli: Расул пошел на охоту с собакой

The variants *-kʷan* and *-kan* are attested in Kina, Luchek, Amsar and Kiche, *-fan* is attested in Ikhrek and Khnov, *-xan* is attested in Ikhrek and Rutul. The last variant, *-xʷan* is attested everywhere except Kina, Luchek and Khnov. The label OTHER is used if the meaning is expressed by means other than a nominal suffix but by a construction with a locative copula: *χana*, *χan*, *xʷana*.
name: Набисат
schooling: 2 in Myukhrek, till 10th grade in Kalmykia
stimuli: Расул на машине поехал в Махачкалу

The variants *-kʷan* and *-kan* are attested in Kina, Luchek, Amsar and Kiche, *-fan* is attested in Ikhrek and Khnov, *-xan* is attested in Ikhrek and Rutul. The last variant, *-xʷan* is attested everywhere except Kina, Luchek and Khnov. The label OTHER is used if the meaning is expressed by means other than a nominal suffix but by a construction with a locative copula: *χana*, *χan*, *xʷana*.
name: Феруза
stimuli: Расул на машине поехал в Махачкалу

feature_title: Attributive marker
feature_description: Attributive marker can be either *-dɨ*, either *-d*. We asked nine contexts, six with the head ‘knife’: ‘(my) brother's knife’ (dependent noun in attributive, head in nominative), ‘I slaughtered a sheep with (my) brother's knife’ (dependent noun in attributive, head in oblique case), ‘sharp knife’ (dependent adjective, head in nominative), ‘He slaughtered a sheep with a sharp knife’ (dependent adjective, head in oblique case), ‘my knife’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive, head in nominative), ‘He slaughtered a sheep with my knife’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive, head in oblique case). And three contexts with the head ‘dog’: ‘lame dog’ (dependent adjective), ‘my dog’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive), ‘(my) brother's dog’ (dependent noun in attributive). The difference between the words ‘knife’ and ‘dog’ is that ‘knife’ is a noun of 4th gender class, and ‘dog’ — of 3rd gender class. These maps show the variation of attributive markers in these nine contexts.
name: Лейла

We asked nine contexts, six with the head ‘knife’: ‘(my) brother's knife’ (dependent noun in attributive, head in nominative), ‘I slaughtered a sheep with (my) brother's knife’ (dependent noun in attributive, head in oblique case), ‘sharp knife’ (dependent adjective, head in nominative), ‘He slaughtered a sheep with a sharp knife’ (dependent adjective, head in oblique case), ‘my knife’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive, head in nominative), ‘He slaughtered a sheep with my knife’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive, head in oblique case). And three contexts with the head ‘dog’: ‘lame dog’ (dependent adjective), ‘my dog’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive), ‘(my) brother's dog’ (dependent noun in attributive). The difference between the words ‘knife’ and ‘dog’ is that ‘knife’ is a noun of 4th gender class, and ‘dog’ — of 3rd gender class. These maps show the variation of attributive markers in these nine contexts.

We asked nine contexts, six with the head ‘knife’: ‘(my) brother's knife’ (dependent noun in attributive, head in nominative), ‘I slaughtered a sheep with (my) brother's knife’ (dependent noun in attributive, head in oblique case), ‘sharp knife’ (dependent adjective, head in nominative), ‘He slaughtered a sheep with a sharp knife’ (dependent adjective, head in oblique case), ‘my knife’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive, head in nominative), ‘He slaughtered a sheep with my knife’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive, head in oblique case). And three contexts with the head ‘dog’: ‘lame dog’ (dependent adjective), ‘my dog’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive), ‘(my) brother's dog’ (dependent noun in attributive). The difference between the words ‘knife’ and ‘dog’ is that ‘knife’ is a noun of 4th gender class, and ‘dog’ — of 3rd gender class. These maps show the variation of attributive markers in these nine contexts.
name: x
mothers_birthplace: Джилихур мама — тухум dašla; у папы тот же тухум, они родственники; четвероюродные

We asked nine contexts, six with the head ‘knife’: ‘(my) brother's knife’ (dependent noun in attributive, head in nominative), ‘I slaughtered a sheep with (my) brother's knife’ (dependent noun in attributive, head in oblique case), ‘sharp knife’ (dependent adjective, head in nominative), ‘He slaughtered a sheep with a sharp knife’ (dependent adjective, head in oblique case), ‘my knife’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive, head in nominative), ‘He slaughtered a sheep with my knife’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive, head in oblique case). And three contexts with the head ‘dog’: ‘lame dog’ (dependent adjective), ‘my dog’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive), ‘(my) brother's dog’ (dependent noun in attributive). The difference between the words ‘knife’ and ‘dog’ is that ‘knife’ is a noun of 4th gender class, and ‘dog’ — of 3rd gender class. These maps show the variation of attributive markers in these nine contexts.
name: мафият

We asked nine contexts, six with the head ‘knife’: ‘(my) brother's knife’ (dependent noun in attributive, head in nominative), ‘I slaughtered a sheep with (my) brother's knife’ (dependent noun in attributive, head in oblique case), ‘sharp knife’ (dependent adjective, head in nominative), ‘He slaughtered a sheep with a sharp knife’ (dependent adjective, head in oblique case), ‘my knife’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive, head in nominative), ‘He slaughtered a sheep with my knife’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive, head in oblique case). And three contexts with the head ‘dog’: ‘lame dog’ (dependent adjective), ‘my dog’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive), ‘(my) brother's dog’ (dependent noun in attributive). The difference between the words ‘knife’ and ‘dog’ is that ‘knife’ is a noun of 4th gender class, and ‘dog’ — of 3rd gender class. These maps show the variation of attributive markers in these nine contexts.
name: рамин

The difference between the words ‘knife’ and ‘dog’ is that ‘knife’ is a noun of 4th gender class, and ‘dog’ — of 3rd gender class. These maps show the variation of attributive markers in these nine contexts.
