feature_title: Temporary possessor form
feature_description: Temporary possessor is a participant that carries a possessum but who does not own it (cf. *I do not have your book with me*). We elicited two contexts: ‘Do not search for your passport, I have it’ and ‘Who has a pen?’. We considered the reaction to the first context as primary evidence. The maps show the forms of pronouns ‘I’ and ‘who’ in these contexts. The attested variants for ‘I’ include *zada*, *zadɨ*, *zad* and *zadda*, and are never identical to the marking used in possessive predication (see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/011_Marking_of_possessor_in_possessive_predication.html)). The second context is probably ambiguous, because some consultants used the form (*halɨχda*) that was used in possessive predication, which we believe suggests “permanent” interpretation of the context with pragmatic inference of having it also here and now, such cases are labeled as OTHER. The attested variants for ‘who’ include *halda* and *haldɨ*.
name: Лейла

feature_title: Temporary possessor form
feature_description: Temporary possessor is a participant that carries a possessum but who does not own it (cf. *I do not have your book with me*). We elicited two contexts: ‘Do not search for your passport, I have it’ and ‘Who has a pen?’. We considered the reaction to the first context as primary evidence. The maps show the forms of pronouns ‘I’ and ‘who’ in these contexts. The attested variants for ‘I’ include *zada*, *zadɨ*, *zad* and *zadda*, and are never identical to the marking used in possessive predication (see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/011_Marking_of_possessor_in_possessive_predication.html)). The second context is probably ambiguous, because some consultants used the form (*halɨχda*) that was used in possessive predication, which we believe suggests “permanent” interpretation of the context with pragmatic inference of having it also here and now, such cases are labeled as OTHER. The attested variants for ‘who’ include *halda* and *haldɨ*.

name: Халисат

feature_title: Marking of personal lative
feature_description: We elicited the context with a personal lative construction: ‘Come to Rasul's (place) in the evening’. The map shows the marking on the noun ‘Rasul’. The attested variants include: case markers *-χda* / *-χdɨ* / *-χd*, *-k* (attested only in Khnov), *-χdal* (attested with only one consultant, in Khnov) and noun in attributive with a postposition — *-dɨ bejda* (attested only in Kiche).
name: Лейла

feature_title: Marking of personal essive
feature_description: We elicited the context with a personal essive (chezative, being at X’s place) construction: ‘Rasul lives at Magomed’s (place)’. The map shows the marking on the noun ‘Magomed’. The attested variants include: case markers — *-xʷan*, *-χda*, *-k*, noun phrases — *-dɨ χal(a)* ‘at X’s house’ and *-dɨ ǯigi(j)* ‘at X's place’. In Shinaz for some speakers it is possible to employ *ǯigi(j)* without dependent attributive marker *-dɨ*.
name: Лейла

feature_title: Marking of personal lative
feature_description: We elicited the context with a personal lative construction: ‘Come to Rasul's (place) in the evening’. The map shows the marking on the noun ‘Rasul’. The attested variants include: case markers — *-xʷan*, *-χda*, *-k*, noun phrases — *-dɨ χal(a)* ‘at X’s house’ and *-dɨ ǯigi(j)* ‘at X's place’. In Shinaz for some speakers it is possible to employ *ǯigi(j)* without dependent attributive marker *-dɨ*.
name: Али

feature_title: Marking of personal lative
feature_description: We elicited the context with a personal lative construction: ‘Come to Rasul's (place) in the evening’. The map shows the marking on the noun ‘Rasul’. The attested variants include: case markers *-χda* / *-χdɨ* / *-χd*, *-k* (attested only in Khnov), *-χdal* (attested with only one consultant, in Khnov) and noun in attributive with a postposition — *-dɨ bejda* (attested only in Kiche).
name: Кавказ

The attested variants include: case markers — *-xʷan*, *-χda*, *-k*, noun phrases — *-dɨ χal(a)* ‘at X’s house’ and *-dɨ ǯigi(j)* ‘at X's place’. In Shinaz for some speakers it is possible to employ *ǯigi(j)* without dependent attributive marker *-dɨ*.

feature_description: The maps show the marking of the standard of comparison in comparative constructions. We elicited two contexts: ‘The mother is kinder than the father’ and ‘A pear is sweeter than an apple’. Attested markers are as follows: *-ɨːla* / *-iːla* (and other phonetic variants), *-qa* / *-qaʔ*, *-qana* (attested with only one consultant, in Kiche), *-χda* (attested with only one consultant, in Dzhilikhur).

feature_title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘on top of’
feature_description: We elicited the context ‘The butterfly is on the flower’. The map shows the marking on the noun ‘flower’. The attested variants include: *-iː* / *-ɨː* / *-ij* / *-ɨ* / *-i* and *-j* (attested only in Ikhrek). We consider *-ij* and *-j* to be phenomena of different nature. We assume the latter to be a separate marker used in Ikhrek, following (Ibragimov 2004: 174). As for the former, it is a phonetic variant of marker *-iː / -ɨː / -ij / -ɨ / -i*, that was attested with only one consultant, in Amsar.

The attested variants include: case markers — *-da* / *-dɨ* / *-de* / *-d*, *-a* (attested with only one consultant, in Khnov) and noun in attributive form with spatial postpositions — *-dɨ bejda* / *-dɨ bejdɨ* / *-dɨ begede*, *-dɨ surudɨ* (attested with only one consultant, in Luchek), *-dɨ janda* (attested only in Khnov).
name: Гюльджаран
long_periods_outside: училась в педе в дербенте, кроме этого ничего; учительница начальных классов

feature_title: Marking of personal elative
feature_description: We elicited two contexts with personal elative construction: ‘(Mom will be back soon), she has left Fatima’s (place)’ and ‘The guests have left Rasul’s (place)’. The map shows the marking on the nouns ‘Fatima’ and ‘Rasul’. The attested variants include: case markers *-χdaː*, *-qla* / *-χla*, *-kla* / *-klʲa*, *-aːla* and the noun in attributive with a postposition — *-dɨ ǯigijaː* / *-d ǯigijaː*, *-d ǯigijaːla*. In one case in Shinaz the postposition *ǯigijaː* is attached directly to the absolutive form. Noun phrase *-d χalaː* ‘from one’s house’ is also attested once (Amsar).
name: Лейла

The attested variants include: case markers *-χdaː*, *-qla* / *-χla*, *-kla* / *-klʲa*, *-aːla* and the noun in attributive with a postposition — *-dɨ ǯigijaː* / *-d ǯigijaː*, *-d ǯigijaːla*. In one case in Shinaz the postposition *ǯigijaː* is attached directly to the absolutive form. Noun phrase *-d χalaː* ‘from one’s house’ is also attested once (Amsar).
name: Зейнаб

feature_description: We elicited two contexts with personal elative construction: ‘(Mom will be back soon), she has left Fatima’s (place)’ and ‘The guests have left Rasul’s (place)’. The map shows the marking on the nouns ‘Fatima’ and ‘Rasul’. The attested variants include: case markers *-χdaː*, *-qla* / *-χla*, *-kla* / *-klʲa*, *-aːla* and the noun in attributive with a postposition — *-dɨ ǯigijaː* / *-d ǯigijaː*, *-d ǯigijaːla*. In one case in Shinaz the postposition *ǯigijaː* is attached directly to the absolutive form. Noun phrase *-d χalaː* ‘from one’s house’ is also attested once (Amsar).
name: Муслимат
long_periods_outside: в Махачкале закончила университет - филологический факультет

The attested variants include: *-qla* / *-qlaː* / *-qlaːl* / *-χla* / *-χlaː*, *-aːla* / *-aːl*, *-χdaː* (attested only in Ikhrek), *-kʲla* / *-klʲa* / *-klʲaː*, *-dɨgɨr* (attested only in Khnov) and *-aːda* / *-dːa* / *-daː* / *-da*.
name: Кизиль

feature_title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘from under’
feature_description: We elicited the context ‘The snake came from under the stone’. The map shows the marking on the noun ‘stone’. The attested variants include: case markers *-qla* / *-qlaː* / *-qlal* / *-χla*, *-xʲdaː*, *-χdaː*, *-χdɨgɨr*, *-kla* / *-kʲla* / *-xʲlʲa* and attributive form of a noun with spatial postpositions — *-d q'anʲäχla* / *-d q'aneχla*, *-d q'anixʲdaː*, *-dɨ q'aneχdɨgɨr*, *-d q'anaklaː* / *-dɨ q'ʷanakʲlʲaː*.
name: Индира

feature_title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘towards inside a mass’
feature_description: We elicited the context ‘I added (some) flour into the dough’. The map shows the case marking on the noun ‘dough’. The attested variants include: *-k* / *-kʲ* and *-šdä* (attested with only one consultant, in Kiche).
name: Назелле

feature_title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘inside a mass’
feature_description: We elicited the context ‘There are a lot of fish in the water’. The map shows the case marking on the noun ‘water’. The attested variants include: *-a* / *-e* / ZERO (*xij-e* in Kina, *xid-a* / *šid-a* in Khnov and *xi* in Kala), *-xde* / *-šde* (*xidi-xde* / *xidi-šde* in Kiche and *xidɨ-xde* / *xidɨ-šde* in Kufa), *-kʲ* / *-k* (elsewhere, various forms: *xidɨ-k*, *xi-k*, *xiji-kʲ*, etc.) and *-xʲ* (attested with only one consultant, in Kufa). The full forms of the noun are given in brackets. While the oblique stems may vary across villages, these differences are not considered in this particular feature. For variation in oblique stem formation, see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/026_Oblique_stem_of_the_noun_%E2%80%98water%E2%80%99.html).
name: Лейла

feature_title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘in between’
feature_description: We elicited the context ‘Musa hid in between the stones’. The map shows the marking on the noun ‘stones’. The attested variants include: case marker *-χda* and attributive form of a noun with spatial postpositions — *-dɨ jɨˁqʼaχda*, *-d jɨˁqʼa* / *-d jɨˁqʼ* and *-d arida* / *-d aride* / *-d arɨdɨ*, *-d arij* / *-dɨ arij*.
name: Назелле

feature_title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘in contact on top of’
feature_description: We elicited the context ‘There is a stain on the table’. The map shows the case marking on the noun ‘table’. The attested variants include: *-k* / *-kʲ*, *-a*, *-j* (in Ikhrek) and *-xde* (attested with only one consultant, in Kiche).
name: Лейла

feature_description: We elicited the context ‘There is a stain on the table’. The map shows the case marking on the noun ‘table’. The attested variants include: *-k* / *-kʲ*, *-a*, *-j* (in Ikhrek) and *-xde* (attested with only one consultant, in Kiche).
name: Зейнаб

feature_title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘in contact with’
feature_description: We elicited the context ‘The painting is on the wall’. The map shows the case marking on the noun ‘wall’. The attested variants include: *-k* / *-kʲ*, *-χda* / *-χd*, *-χdɨgɨr* (attested with only one consultant, in Khnov), *-a* (attested only in Khnov) and *-ɨ* (attested with only one consultant, in Ikhrek).
name: Зейнаб

feature_title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘towards inside a mass’
feature_description: We elicited the context ‘I added (some) flour into the dough’. The map shows the case marking on the noun ‘dough’. The attested variants include: *-k* / *-kʲ* and *-šdä* (attested with only one consultant, in Kiche).
name: Джалал

feature_title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘inside a mass’
feature_description: We elicited the context ‘There are a lot of fish in the water’. The map shows the case marking on the noun ‘water’. The attested variants include: *-a* / *-e* / ZERO (*xij-e* in Kina, *xid-a* / *šid-a* in Khnov and *xi* in Kala), *-xde* / *-šde* (*xidi-xde* / *xidi-šde* in Kiche and *xidɨ-xde* / *xidɨ-šde* in Kufa), *-kʲ* / *-k* (elsewhere, various forms: *xidɨ-k*, *xi-k*, *xiji-kʲ*, etc.) and *-xʲ* (attested with only one consultant, in Kufa). The full forms of the noun are given in brackets. While the oblique stems may vary across villages, these differences are not considered in this particular feature. For variation in oblique stem formation, see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/026_Oblique_stem_of_the_noun_%E2%80%98water%E2%80%99.html).
name: Джалал

feature_title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘in between’
feature_description: We elicited the context ‘Musa hid in between the stones’. The map shows the marking on the noun ‘stones’. The attested variants include: case marker *-χda* and attributive form of a noun with spatial postpositions — *-dɨ jɨˁqʼaχda*, *-d jɨˁqʼa* / *-d jɨˁqʼ* and *-d arida* / *-d aride* / *-d arɨdɨ*, *-d arij* / *-dɨ arij*.

The attested variants include: *-a* / *-e* / ZERO (*xij-e* in Kina, *xid-a* / *šid-a* in Khnov and *xi* in Kala), *-xde* / *-šde* (*xidi-xde* / *xidi-šde* in Kiche and *xidɨ-xde* / *xidɨ-šde* in Kufa), *-kʲ* / *-k* (elsewhere, various forms: *xidɨ-k*, *xi-k*, *xiji-kʲ*, etc.) and *-xʲ* (attested with only one consultant, in Kufa). The full forms of the noun are given in brackets. While the oblique stems may vary across villages, these differences are not considered in this particular feature. For variation in oblique stem formation, see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/026_Oblique_stem_of_the_noun_%E2%80%98water%E2%80%99.html).
name: Марита

feature_title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘in between’

comment: Первая реакция: барийахдыгыр (мусара сахъушури шикил' барийахдыгыр), затем ее отрицает "это то что, она висит". Потом сказал, что нужно барийадыгыр и барийа:ла, потом сказал, что барийадыгыр значит за стеной, потом сказал, что оно же значит "со стены" (т. е. то, что нам нужно...). Барийигыр - через стену (Барийигыр гуьлле егъипы кивихъыри - пуля прошла стену и попала). Барийахды - "на стене". Сувахдыгыр не идет?? Очень запутанно, поэтому кодирую только барийа:ла.

feature_title: Lexical item for ‘cowshed’
feature_description: We elicited the word for ‘cattle shed’ in the context ‘Cow is in the cattle shed’. The noun was elicited in the inessive. On the map, the stems of the lexical items are shown rather than their full forms in the context. The stems are not necessarily actual oblique stems, but rather labels that represent the lexemes. feature_title: Oblique stem of the noun ‘water’
feature_description: We elicited the form of the noun 'water' in the context ‘There are a lot of fish in the water’. The map shows the variation in the oblique stem of the noun. The attested variants include: *xid-* / *šid-* (Ikhrek, Khnov, Rutul, Kufa and Kiche), *xi-* (Shinaz and partly Kala), and *xij-* (elsewhere). To see the differences in case marking observed in this context, see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/019_Marking_of_topological_relation_%E2%80%98inside_a_mass%E2%80%99.html).

The attested variants include: *xid-* / *šid-* (Ikhrek, Khnov, Rutul, Kufa and Kiche), *xi-* (Shinaz and partly Kala), and *xij-* (elsewhere). To see the differences in case marking observed in this context, see [feature](https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/019_Marking_of_topological_relation_%E2%80%98inside_a_mass%E2%80%99.html).
name: Мехти

feature_title: Agreement in obliqueness
feature_description: The map shows whether the form of the attributive (possessor) noun depends on the case of the head noun (agreement in obliqueness). We elicited three contexts: ‘(my) brother's knife’ (the head noun ‘knife’ is in the nominative and belongs to Gender 4), ‘I slaughtered a sheep with (my) brother's knife’ (the head noun ‘knife’ is in an oblique case and belongs to Gender 4), ‘(my) brother's dog’ (the head noun ‘dog’ is in the nominative and belongs to Gender 3). In Ikhrek and Khnov, the first contexts shows the attributive suffix *-d* (*šuˤ-d kantʼ* [brother-ATTR knife]), and -dɨ in the two other contexts *-dɨ* (*šuˤ-dɨ kantʼi-fan* [brother-ATTR knife.OBL-COMIT]; *šuˤ-dɨ χij* [brother-ATTR dog]). In other dialects the suffix *-dɨ* is used in all contexts. In (Tairova 2010) it is claimed that the same two variants of the attributive suffix are distributed depending on the gender and number of the head in Myukhrek; no details are given as to the case of the head. We cannot directly confirm this based on our data, because, for Myukhrek, the three contexts come from different consultants, so Myukhrek is not shown on the map. However, if we merge the data coming from all consultants, Myukhrek does group not with Khnov and Ikhrek but with the other dialects; and does not confirm Tairova's [-@tairova2010] account.
name: Лейла
stimuli: Нож брата. Я зарезал овцу ножом брата. Собака брата
answer: šud kantʼ ; šud kantʼikʷan ; šud tɨla

feature_description: The map shows whether the form of the attributive (possessor) noun depends on the case of the head noun (agreement in obliqueness). We elicited three contexts: ‘(my) brother's knife’ (the head noun ‘knife’ is in the nominative and belongs to Gender 4), ‘I slaughtered a sheep with (my) brother's knife’ (the head noun ‘knife’ is in an oblique case and belongs to Gender 4), ‘(my) brother's dog’ (the head noun ‘dog’ is in the nominative and belongs to Gender 3). In Ikhrek and Khnov, the first contexts shows the attributive suffix *-d* (*šuˤ-d kantʼ* [brother-ATTR knife]), and -dɨ in the two other contexts *-dɨ* (*šuˤ-dɨ kantʼi-fan* [brother-ATTR knife.OBL-COMIT]; *šuˤ-dɨ χij* [brother-ATTR dog]). In other dialects the suffix *-dɨ* is used in all contexts. In (Tairova 2010) it is claimed that the same two variants of the attributive suffix are distributed depending on the gender and number of the head in Myukhrek; no details are given as to the case of the head. We cannot directly confirm this based on our data, because, for Myukhrek, the three contexts come from different consultants, so Myukhrek is not shown on the map. However, if we merge the data coming from all consultants, Myukhrek does group not with Khnov and Ikhrek but with the other dialects; and does not confirm Tairova's [-@tairova2010] account.
name: Тайбат
residence_place: Makhachkala, совсем недавно переехали в город и теперь приезжают на лето??
stimuli: Нож брата. Я зарезал овцу ножом брата. Собака брата
answer: kantʼ šuˤd ; jiǯ hupkuri tʼex šuˤdɨ kantʼifan ; —

In Ikhrek and Khnov, the first contexts shows the attributive suffix *-d* (*šuˤ-d kantʼ* [brother-ATTR knife]), and -dɨ in the two other contexts *-dɨ* (*šuˤ-dɨ kantʼi-fan* [brother-ATTR knife.OBL-COMIT]; *šuˤ-dɨ χij* [brother-ATTR dog]). In other dialects the suffix *-dɨ* is used in all contexts. In (Tairova 2010) it is claimed that the same two variants of the attributive suffix are distributed depending on the gender and number of the head in Myukhrek; no details are given as to the case of the head. We cannot directly confirm this based on our data, because, for Myukhrek, the three contexts come from different consultants, so Myukhrek is not shown on the map. However, if we merge the data coming from all consultants, Myukhrek does group not with Khnov and Ikhrek but with the other dialects; and does not confirm Tairova's [-@tairova2010] account.
name: Назиле
schooling: Kufa до 4 класса, потом в Рутуле
stimuli: Нож брата. Я зарезал овцу ножом брата. Собака брата
